articles.headline: Merck Says Niacin Drug Has Failed Large Trial
articles.snippet: The combination did not protect against heart attacks and strokes in a large clinical trial, and the company said it would no longer pursue its approval in the United States.
articles.abstract: The combination did not protect against heart attacks and strokes in a large clinical trial, and the company said it would no longer pursue its approval in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: The drug maker Merck announced on Thursday that a combination of niacin and another medicine failed to protect against heart attacks and strokes in a large clinical trial, and that the company would no longer pursue approval of the combination drug in the United States.

articles.headline: Boehner Cancels Tax Vote in Face of G.O.P. Revolt
articles.snippet: Speaker John A. Boehner abruptly halted efforts to pass fallback legislation to prevent a fiscal crisis after conservative Republicans refused to allow taxes to rise even on the most affluent.
articles.abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner abruptly halted efforts to pass fallback legislation to prevent a fiscal crisis after conservative Republicans refused to allow taxes to rise even on the most affluent.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker John A. Boehner’s effort to pass fallback legislation to avert a fiscal crisis in less than two weeks collapsed Thursday night in an embarrassing defeat after conservative Republicans refused to support legislation that would allow taxes to rise on the most affluent households in the country.

articles.headline: In Japan, a Test of Inflation Targets
articles.snippet: For two decades, Japan has provided stark evidence that chronic deflation is possible in a modern economy. Now, its central bank appears ready to do whatever it takes to get inflation.
articles.abstract: For two decades, Japan has provided stark evidence that chronic deflation is possible in a modern economy. Now, its central bank appears ready to do whatever it takes to get inflation.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Under a paper-money system, a determined government can always generate higher spending and, hence, positive inflation.”

articles.headline: Peter Madoff Is Sentenced to 10 Years for His Role in Fraud
articles.snippet: Peter Madoff, Bernard L. Madoff’s younger brother, was sentenced to 10 years in prison on Thursday for his role in enabling the extensive fraud that swindled investors out of billions of dollars.
articles.abstract: Peter Madoff, Bernard L. Madoff’s younger brother, was sentenced to 10 years in prison on Thursday for his role in enabling the extensive fraud that swindled investors out of billions of dollars.
articles.byline: By Peter Lattman and DIANA B. HENRIQUES

articles.headline: Instagram Does an About-Face
articles.snippet: After an uproar over privacy concerns, Instagram’s co-founder, Kevin Systrom, said the service would revert to its previous user agreement.
articles.abstract: After an uproar over privacy concerns, Instagram’s co-founder, Kevin Systrom, said the service would revert to its previous user agreement.
articles.lead_paragraph: 11:14 p.m. | Updated SAN FRANCISCO — In the aftermath of the uproar over changes to Instagram’s privacy policy and terms of service earlier this week, the company did an about-face late Thursday.
articles.byline: By Nicole Perlroth and Jenna Wortham

articles.headline: Marijuana, Not Yet Legal for Californians, Might as Well Be
articles.snippet: Marijuana can be smelled in suburban backyards in neighborhoods from Hollywood to Topanga Canyon as dusk falls — what in other places is known as the cocktail hour.
articles.abstract: Marijuana can be smelled in suburban backyards in neighborhoods from Hollywood to Topanga Canyon as dusk falls — what in other places is known as the cocktail hour.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Let Colorado and Washington be the marijuana trailblazers. Let them struggle with the messy details of what it means to actually legalize the drug. Marijuana is, as a practical matter, already legal in much of California.

articles.headline: ICE Deal for N.Y.S.E. Creates Global Powerhouse
articles.snippet: The New York Stock Exchange once had a monopoly on stock trading, but is no longer the center of the financial world.
articles.abstract: The New York Stock Exchange once had a monopoly on stock trading, but is no longer the center of the financial world.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was the temple of commerce, the symbol of New York’s status as the nation’s — and for many decades, the world’s — financial center.

articles.headline: At the Big Board, Seeking Rejuvenation in Consolidation
articles.snippet: An acquisition that made sense for a flagging New York Stock Exchange and a newcomer with heft in the derivatives market.
articles.abstract: An acquisition that made sense for a flagging New York Stock Exchange and a newcomer with heft in the derivatives market.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the chief executive of IntercontinentalExchange approached his counterpart at NYSE Euronext about a merger in late September, they quickly came to terms, hashing out a deal in only three months.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Exchange Sale Reflects New Realities of Trading
articles.snippet: IntercontinentalExchange’s $8.2 billion takeover of the New York Stock Exchange illustrates starkly how trading in commodities and derivatives has become much more lucrative than trading in the shares of companies.
articles.abstract: IntercontinentalExchange’s $8.2 billion takeover of the New York Stock Exchange illustrates starkly how trading in commodities and derivatives has become much more lucrative than trading in the shares of companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a warm day in Boca Raton, Fla., the host of a reception for an annual financial conference was not a big bank or a powerful exchange as in years past, but a young firm based in Atlanta.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Nathaniel Popper

articles.headline: Gaps in F.B.I. Data Undercut Background Checks for Guns
articles.snippet: Significant gaps in the F.B.I.’s database of criminal and mental health records allow thousands of people to buy firearms every year who should be barred from doing so.
articles.abstract: Significant gaps in the F.B.I.’s database of criminal and mental health records allow thousands of people to buy firearms every year who should be barred from doing so.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLARKSBURG, W.Va. — Nearly two decades after lawmakers began requiring background checks for gun buyers, significant gaps in the F.B.I.’s database of criminal and mental health records allow thousands of people to buy firearms every year who should be barred from doing so.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Syria Unleashes Cluster Bombs on Town, Punishing Civilians
articles.snippet: Cluster bombs are impossible to use precisely, and the victims of such attacks describe them as collective punishment against populations that side with the rebels.
articles.abstract: Cluster bombs are impossible to use precisely, and the victims of such attacks describe them as collective punishment against populations that side with the rebels.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAREA, Syria — The plane came in from the southeast late in the afternoon, releasing its weapons in a single pass. Within seconds, scores of finned bomblets struck and exploded on the homes and narrow streets of this small Syrian town.

articles.headline: Debt Ceiling Rises Again as Threat for the U.S.
articles.snippet: Financial markets and credit rating agencies are closely watching both the talks on the fiscal impasse and the raising of the debt ceiling.
articles.abstract: Financial markets and credit rating agencies are closely watching both the talks on the fiscal impasse and the raising of the debt ceiling.
articles.lead_paragraph: The three major ratings agencies shrugged off this week’s breakdown in talks aimed at ending the fiscal impasse in Washington by Jan. 1, saying their outlook for America’s sovereign debt was already negative and would not immediately change.

articles.headline: Obama Presses Stripped-Down Plan to Limit Tax Increase
articles.snippet: President Obama, conceding that a “grand bargain” for deficit reduction with Speaker John A. Boehner is unlikely, called for Congress to approve a more modest measure by year’s end.
articles.abstract: President Obama, conceding that a “grand bargain” for deficit reduction with Speaker John A. Boehner is unlikely, called for Congress to approve a more modest measure by year’s end.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, conceding that a “grand bargain” for deficit reduction with Speaker John A. Boehner is unlikely, called Friday for Congress to approve a stripped-down measure by year’s end to prevent a tax increase for all but the richest taxpayers and to extend aid for two million unemployed Americans.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: Kerry Named for the Role of a Lifetime
articles.snippet: The appointment of Senator John Kerry, an established Obama loyalist, to be secretary of state is likely to further centralize decisions in the White House.
articles.abstract: The appointment of Senator John Kerry, an established Obama loyalist, to be secretary of state is likely to further centralize decisions in the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With a patrician bearing, nearly three decades of service on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, a highly decorated combat career in the Vietnam War, even a father who was a diplomat, John Kerry is the very picture of a secretary of state.
